awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Computationally Predicting and Characterizing the Immune Response to Viral Infections
awd_abstract_narration:
Pathogens such as the Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) affect different people differently.  Whether an individual mounts a strong response or not depends, at least in part, on their genes. Specific genes code for the proteins on the surface of cells that present viral protein fragments to the immune system. Killer T cells recognize these fragments and kill the infected cells. The immune response to SARS-CoV-2 hinges on whether the viral protein fragments bind into a groove in these cell-surface proteins -- like a key into a lock. The molecular biology is well understood. Whether a protein fragment binds or not is a question of 3D structure and simple atomic force calculations. The full set of proteins associated with  SARS-CoV-2  was published in March, so the requisite data is available. This project will predict, through purely computational means, whether such binding happens for all viral protein fragments, for all common variants of the cell surface proteins -- so for all keys into all types of locks.  This computational ability will be  transformative for a scientific understanding of the pandemic  If successful, the same computational infrastructure could be deployed in the future for other pandemics -- those caused by viruses or by bacteria. It could also be transformative in characterizing the human immune system, in general, and its response to pathogens. 

In technical terms, the goal of the project is to predict, through computational means, which peptides derived from SARS- CoV-2 will bind to each allelic variant of MHC-I molecule commonly found in the U.S. population. Human leukocyte antigen (HLA) typing can be performed to establish the allelic variants of MHC-I molecules of individuals. With population-wide typing, the tools developed by this project will predict which individuals in a population are most likely to mount a strong antiviral immune response to the virus, given their MHC-I alleles. Immunopeptidome profiling will be performed of all common allelic variants of MHC-I molecules, first using machine-learning algorithms. Next immunopeptidome profiling will be performed using custom-developed atomic-level simulation software, deployed on graphical processing units.The project will provide a public implementation of the tool set. The results of the research will be promptly disseminated on a website hosted by the University of Minnesota. The front-end will exploit modern software infrastructure for data analytics and visualization. The back-end will consist of a MySQL database, directly linked to the computational engine, running on a distributed platform.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Pathogens such as Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) affect different people differently. Whether an individual mounts a strong response or not depends, at least in part, on their genes. Specific genes code for proteins on the surface of cells that present viral protein fragments to the immune system. Killer T cells recognize these fragments and kill the infected cells. The immune response to SARS-CoV-2 hinges on whether the viral protein fragments bind into a groove in these cell-surface proteins -- like a key into a lock. The molecular biology is well understood. Whether a protein fragment binds or not is a question of 3D structure and simple atomic force calculations. The full set of proteins associated with SARS-CoV-2 was published early in the pandemic, so the requisite data is available. The goal of this project was to provide tools that can predict, through purely computational means, whether such binding occurs for all viral protein fragments, for all common variants of the cell surface proteins -- for all keys into all types of locks. This computational ability will be transformative for scientific understanding of the pandemic. The same computational infrastructure can be deployed in the future for other pandemics -- those caused by viruses or bacteria. It could also be transformative in characterizing the human immune system in general and its response to pathogens. 
Stated more technically, the goal of the project was to predict, through computational means, which peptides derived from SARS-CoV-2 will bind to each variant of cell-surface receptors commonly found in the U.S. population. Human leukocyte antigen (HLA) typing, used for paternity testing, can be performed to establish the variants. With population-wide typing, the tools developed by this project can predict which individuals in a population are most likely to mount a strong antiviral immune response to the virus.
The Omicron variants boast the highest infectivity rates among all SARS-CoV-2 variants to date. Despite its lower disease severity, it can reinfect former COVID-19 patients and infect vaccinated individuals. The high number of mutations in new variants renders them resistant to antibodies that otherwise neutralize the spike protein of the original SARS-CoV-2. Recent research has shown that despite its strong immune evasion, Omicron still induces strong T-cell responses similar to the original variant. This work investigated the molecular basis for this observation using neural network tools. The antigens presented through different pathways from all the notable SARS-CoV-2 variants were compared across numerous high-frequency HLAs.
Bias in neural network model training datasets has been observed to decrease prediction accuracy for groups underrepresented in training data. Therefore, investigating the composition of training datasets used in machine learning models with healthcare applications is vital to ensure equity. Machine learning models are used to predict antigen binding scores. Antigen presentation is a critical step in mounting an adaptive immune response, and previous work has used these or similar prediction models in a broad array of applications, from explaining asymptomatic viral infection to cancer neoantigen prediction. However, these models have also been shown to be biased toward hydrophobic peptides, suggesting that the network could contain other sources of bias. In this project, we reported that the composition of the networks’ training datasets is heavily biased toward European Caucasian individuals and against Asian and Pacific Islander individuals. We test the neural networks' ability to distinguish true binders from randomly generated peptides on alleles not included in the training datasets.
Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC) Class I molecules allow cells to present foreign and endogenous peptides to T cells so that cells infected by pathogens can be identified and killed. Neural network tools are used to predict whether peptides will bind to variants of MHC molecules. These tools are trained on data gathered from binding affinity and eluted ligand experiments. However, these tools do not track hydrophobicity, a significant biochemical factor relevant to peptide binding, in their predictions. A previous study concluded that the peptides predicted to bind to some variants were much more hydrophobic than expected. Two studies were performed, one using the data on which the neural networks were trained, and the other using a sample of the human proteome. The neural networks were found to have a statistically significant bias toward predicting highly hydrophobic peptides as strong binders in both studies. Machine learning metrics were used to identify the causes for this bias: hydrophobic false positives and hydrophilic false negatives. These results suggest that retraining the neural networks with biochemical attributes such as hydrophobicity and better training data could increase the accuracy of their predictions. This would enhance their impact in applications such as vaccine design and neoantigen identification.
